Version 1.0.0.0


IBM Navigator Java SDK Home


This site is a comprehensive resource for all materials relating to the 
IBM Content 
Navigator
 Java SDK, including all of the sample code for desktop and mobile as well as the JavaDocs. Please see the 
overview section
 for further details as well as the 
notices section
 for licensing infomation. 




References






Android SDK sample






Command line SDK sample






Watson integration command line SDK sample






Official Javadocs for the SDK
  






Support forum on developerWorks
docs.title: Home

docs.text:
This site is a comprehensive resource for all materials relating to the  IBM Content 
Navigator  Java SDK, including all of the sample code for desktop and mobile as well as the JavaDocs. Please see the  overview section  for further details as well as the  notices section  for licensing infomation.
docs.title: IBM Navigator Java SDK Home

docs.text: Android SDK sample    Command line SDK sample    Watson integration command line SDK sample    Official Javadocs for the SDK       Support forum on developerWorks
docs.title: References

docs.text:
Overview


You can build high-quality desktop (non-mobile) and mobile apps for the Android platforms with the IBM Navigator 
Java Software Development Kit. This release supports both IBM FileNet Content Manager 
and IBM Content Manager repositories.


Here are the main goals of the software development kit (SDK):




High performance


Low memory requirements


Asynchronous operation 


Encapsulation of implementation details like networking, serialization and security token management. 


Expose the same object model as the iOS version of the SDK so that developers will feel comfortable moving between Java and Swift when needed. 


Allow for the same binary Jar file to be used for both Desktop and Mobile development. 






Here are some of the tasks that you can perform with the SDK:




Connect and log in to an on-premises IBM Content Navigator server. 


View all documents and properties in a Navigator repository.


Add and remove documents in a Navigator repository.


Search for content in a Navigator repository.


Use search templates to search for content in a Content Navigator repository.


Use teamspaces to manage content and users.


Use favorites to quickly access content.


Sync content to keep it up to date.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text:
You can build high-quality desktop (non-mobile) and mobile apps for the Android platforms with the IBM Navigator 
Java Software Development Kit. This release supports both IBM FileNet Content Manager 
and IBM Content Manager repositories.  Here are the main goals of the software development kit (SDK):   High performance  Low memory requirements  Asynchronous operation   Encapsulation of implementation details like networking, serialization and security token management.   Expose the same object model as the iOS version of the SDK so that developers will feel comfortable moving between Java and Swift when needed.   Allow for the same binary Jar file to be used for both Desktop and Mobile development.     Here are some of the tasks that you can perform with the SDK:   Connect and log in to an on-premises IBM Content Navigator server.   View all documents and properties in a Navigator repository.  Add and remove documents in a Navigator repository.  Search for content in a Navigator repository.  Use search templates to search for content in a Content Navigator repository.  Use teamspaces to manage content and users.  Use favorites to quickly access content.  Sync content to keep it up to date.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text:
Downloading the SDK


To obtain the SDK:






Go to the Fix Central link 
here
 and select the link to download the 
IBM_Navigator_Mobile_Java-1.0.0-SDK
. 






Once you have obtained the distribution zip you will see that it consists of the 
Readme.txt
 and two top level directories.  The 
IBMECMCore_javadocs
 folder contains a snapshot of the javadocs and the 
IBMECMCore_binaries
 folder contains the 
IBMECMCore-1.0.0.jar
 (the SDK jar) and all of its dependencies. (in the ./lib directory).  






See 
Figure 1
 for a image of all of the files in the distribution shown exploded. 


Generally you will need all of the 
./lib
 jars in your project unless you have your Maven or Gradle project setup to get them separately from your own repository.  Minimally you will always need the 
IBMECMCore-1.0.0.jar
 (or later version). 




Figure 1


The contents of the distribution zip file:
docs.title: Downloading the SDK

docs.text: To obtain the SDK:    Go to the Fix Central link  here  and select the link to download the  IBM_Navigator_Mobile_Java-1.0.0-SDK .     Once you have obtained the distribution zip you will see that it consists of the  Readme.txt  and two top level directories.  The  IBMECMCore_javadocs  folder contains a snapshot of the javadocs and the  IBMECMCore_binaries  folder contains the  IBMECMCore-1.0.0.jar  (the SDK jar) and all of its dependencies. (in the ./lib directory).      See  Figure 1  for a image of all of the files in the distribution shown exploded.   Generally you will need all of the  ./lib  jars in your project unless you have your Maven or Gradle project setup to get them separately from your own repository.  Minimally you will always need the  IBMECMCore-1.0.0.jar  (or later version).
docs.title: Downloading the SDK

docs.text: The contents of the distribution zip file:
docs.title: Figure 1

docs.text:
Getting started with the SDK


Package overview


The IBM Navigator Java SDK package includes the following components:


The binary distribution.






See 
Downloading the SDK
 






The binary distribution contains the SDK jar itself and all of its dependencies that we have explicitly tested with this version. 






Official Javadocs for the SDK
  






The Android sample






See 
Android Sample






The Android sample contains a working Android application built with the Navigator SDK.  The application demonstrates how to do basic operations like authentication, browsing folders and documents as well as how to handle threading issues specific to Android. 






The command line sample




The command line 
sample
 contains a command line Java program that you can compile and run inside of 5 minutes.   The program uses connection information for a local ICN server that you provide in a properties file and is run with a single maven command (or Java command) 




Watson integration command line sample


The Watson integration sample 
here
 shows how to apply the SDK as a source of data to the 
Watson Alchemy APIs
.  


Important: The sample projects are intended to show you how to use the SDK. 
  It is not intended to be a tutorial on how to design your application. For example, 
  it does not contain robust error handling and recovery.




SDK details


The SDK uses the Factory pattern and is organized into two sections:

 Factory: Factory methods to obtain all the actual model objects and perform 
high-level tasks.

 Model: The entire model layer that shows the protocols and interfaces that can be called.


For more details on the layout of the SDK and all of its classes see the Javadocs section link in the 
References section


Prerequisites


You are expected to have a working knowledge of IBM Content Navigator, and the Java programming language.


The prerequisites for using the SDK are as follows:




An IBM Content Navigator (2.0.3.5 or later) configured to use an IBM FileNet Content Manager server and/or IBM Content Manager server. 


(Recommended) A recent version of 
Eclipse
 or 
Android Studio
.   Android studio is only required for building Android mobile applications. 


The IBM Navigator Java SDK 1.0.0 or later package. See the 
download page
 for details on downloading the SDK. 


Java Runtime Environment (JRE) 1.7 or later




Integration with your projects


To use the IBM Navigator Java SDK, you must integrate it with an existing or new 
project and this procedure will be different depending on whether the project is a desktop Java application or a Android mobile application. 


(For information on obtaining the SDK please see the 
download section
 )
docs.title: Getting started with the SDK

docs.text:
To use the IBM Navigator Java SDK, you must integrate it with an existing or new 
project and this procedure will be different depending on whether the project is a desktop Java application or a Android mobile application.   (For information on obtaining the SDK please see the  download section  )
docs.title: Integration with your projects
Async versus synchronous operation

docs.text: Applies to  Version 1.0.0.0
docs.title: Synchronous versus Asynchronous modes

docs.text: The current version of the SDK is an asynchronous API.  This makes is especially easy to use in mobile and desktop applications where the SDK is passing back information to a user interface (UI).  Although future versions of the API may support blocking synchronous calls natively, it is very easy to construct blocking wrappers around the API calls when needed with the current version.  To make this process easier we have included several reuseable examples of this in the command line examples.    Specifically look at the  SynchronousWrappers.java  class in the  com.ibm.ecm.api.testutils  package.    This pattern can be duplicated for all of the current SDK methods that are asynchronous.
docs.title: SDK design
Example of wrapping an asynchronous call
